data.title: Chow Yun-fat
data.meta_description: Actors Chow Yun-fat SBS (周润发; born May 18, 1955) is a Hong Kong actor. He started his career in movies in 1976 with Goldig Films, the third largest film company at the time. He first found success came with the TV series The Bund (1980), with Ray Lui, Angie Chiu, Lau Dan, Lam Kin-ming, Kent…
data.text:
Actors

Chow Yun-fat SBS (周润发; born May 18, 1955) is a Hong Kong actor. He started his career in movies in 1976 with Goldig Films, the third largest film company at the time. He first found success came with the TV series The Bund (1980), with Ray Lui, Angie Chiu, Lau Dan, Lam Kin-ming, Kent Tong, and King Doi-yum. Early films include Dennis Yu’s See-Bar (1980), with Dorothy Yu, Roy Chiao, and Pai Ying; Ann Hui’s The Story of Woo Viet (1981), with Cora Miao, Lo Lieh, and Cherie Chung; Ronny Yu’s The Postman Strikes Back (1982), with Bryan Leung, Fan Mei-sheng, Yuen Yat-cho, Eddy Ko, Cherie Chung, and Kuk Ching-suk; Lau Shing-hon’s The Head Hunter (1982), with Rosamund Kwan, Flora Cheong-Leen, Ko Chun-hsiung, Philip Chan, and Tang Ching; Po-Chih Leong’s Hong Kong 1941 (1984), with Cecilia Yip and Alex Man; Why Me? (1985), with Kent Cheng (who also directed) and Olivia Cheng; Ching Siu-tung’s Witch from Nepal (1986), with Emily Chu, Yammie Lam, and Dick Wei; Stanley Kwan’s Love Unto Waste (1986), with Tony Leung, Irene Wan, Elaine Jin, Tsai Chin, Elaine Chow, and Winnie Yu; and Tony Au’s Dream Lovers (1986), with Brigitte Lin.

He gained international stardom in John Woo’s A Better Tomorrow (1987), with Ti Lung, Leslie Cheung, Emily Chu, Waise Lee, and Kenneth Tsang. The would also work together on A Better Tomorrow II (1987), with Lung, Cheung, Dean Shek, and Kwan Shen; The Killer (1989), with Danny Lee, Sally Yeh, Chu Kong, Tsang, and Shing Fui-On; Once a Thief (1991), with Cheung, Cherie Chung, Kenneth Tsang, and Paul Chu; and Hard Boiled (1992), with Tony Leung Chiu-wai, Teresa Mo, Philip Chan, Philip Kwok, and Anthony Wong.

Other ‘gun fu’ or ‘heroic bloodshed’ films include Ringo Lam’s City on Fire (1987), with Danny Lee, Sun Yueh, Carrie Ng, and Roy Cheung; Joe Cheung’s Flaming Brothers (1987), with Alan Tang, Pat Ha, Jenny Tseng, Patrick Tse, James Yi, Philip Chan, and Norman Chui; Taylor Wong’s 2 part film Rich and Famous (1987) & Tragic Hero (1987), collectively with Andy Lau,Alan Tam, Alex Man, Pauline Wong, Carina Lau, Danny Lee, and Ko Chun-hsiung; Prison on Fire (1987), with Tony Leung Ka-fai; Tsui Hark’s A Better Tomorrow 3 (1989), with Tony Leung Ka-fai and Anita Mui; Prison on Fire II (1991), with Chen Sung-young,

Yu Li, Tommy Wong, Victor Hon, Elvis Tsui, and Wan Yeung-ming; and Full Contact (1992), with Simon Yam and Anthony Wong.

Other films in the 80s include Lam Ngai Kai’s The Seventh Curse (1986), with Chin Siu-ho, Dick Wei, Maggie Cheung, and Sibelle Hu; Yee Tung-Shin’s The Lunatics (1986), with Fung Shui-Fan, Deanne Ip, and Paul Chun Pui; 100 Ways to Murder Your Wife (1986), with Kenny Bee (who also directed), Anita Mui, and Joey Wong; Johnny To’s The Eighth Happiness (1988), with Raymond Wong, Jacky Cheung, Carol Cheng, Cherie Chung, Fung Bo Bo, and Fennie Yuen; Chong Wung’s Fractured Follies (1988), with Joey Wong, James Wong, Nina Li Chi, Wong Ching, Bonnie Law, and Mengxia Zheng; Lau Kar-leung’s Tiger on the Beat (1988), with Nina Li Chi, Conan Lee, and Gordon Liu; Corey Yuen’s Diary of a Big Man (1988), with Sally Yeh, Joey Wong, Waise Lee, Carrie Ng, and Kent Cheng; All About Ah-Long (1989), with Sylvia Chang; God of Gamblers (1989), with Andy Lau, Joey Wong, and Sharla Cheung; and Wild Search (1989), with Cherie Chung, Roy Cheung, Tommy Wong, Elaine Jin, Paul Chun, and Ku Feng.

Other films in the 90s include The Fun, the Luck & the Tycoon (1990), with Sylvia Chang, Nina Li Chi, and Lawrence Cheng; Now You See Love, Now You Don’t (1992), with Carol Cheng, Teresa Mo, and Carina Lau; God of Gamblers Returns (1994), with Tony Leung Ka-fai, Sharla Cheung, Charles Heung, Jacklyn Wu, and Chingmy Yau; Jeffery Lau’s Treasure Hunt (1994), with Jacklyn Wu,

Chin Han, Gordon Liu, Michael Wong, Philip Kwok, and Roy Chiao; and Wai Ka-fai’s Peace Hotel (1995), with Cecelia Yip.

He made his Hollywood debut in Antoine Fuqua’s The Replacement Killers (1998), with Mira Sorvino, Michael Rooker, Kenneth Tsang, Jürgen Prochnow, Til Schweiger, Clifton Collins Jr., Danny Trejo, and Randall Duk Kim. This was followed by James Foley’s The Corruptor (1999), with Mark Wahlberg, Ric Young, Paul Ben-Victor, Byron Mann, Brian Cox; and Anna and the King (1990), with Jodie Foster, Bai Ling, and Tom Felton. None were commercially successful, but gained some critical praise.

He then starred in Ang Lee’s Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (2000), with Michelle Yeoh, Zhang Ziyi, Chang Chen, Lang Sihung, and Cheng Pei-pei; which was a worldwide success critically and financially, winning numerous awards including the Academy Award for Best International Film.

Other Hollywood films include. Bulletproof Monk (2003), with Seann William Scott, Jaime King, Karel Roden, Victoria Smurfit, Roger Yuan, and Mako; Gore Verbinski’s Pirates of the Caribbean: At World’s End (2007), with Johnny Depp, Orlando Bloom, Keira Knightley, Stellan Skarsgård, Bill Nighy, Geoffrey Rush, Jack Davenport, Kevin R. McNally, Tom Hollander, Naomie Harris, Lee Arenberg, Mackenzie Crook, and Jonathan Pryce; and Dragonball: Evolution (2009), with Justin Chatwin, Emmy Rossum, James Marsters, Jamie Chung, Joon Park, and Eriko Tamura.

Other films in the mid to late 2000s include The Postmodern Life of My Aunt (2006), with Siqin Gaowa, Zhao Wei, and Lisa Lu; Zhang Yimou’s Curse of the Golden Flower (2006), with Gong Li, Jay Chou, and Qin Junjie; and Roger Spottiswoode’s The Children of Huang Shi (2008), with Jonathan Rhys Meyers, Radha Mitchell, and Yeoh.

Films in the early 2010s include Hu Mei’s Confucius (2010), with Zhou XunChen Jianbin, Ren Quan, Lu Yi, and Yao Lu; Shanghai (2010), with John Cusack, Gong Li, Jeffrey Dean Morgan, David Morse, and Ken Watanabe; Let the Bullets Fly (2010), with Jiang Wen (who also directed), Ge You, Carina Lau, Jiang Wu, Liao Fan, Chen Kun, Zhou Yun, and Zhang Mo; The Assassins (2012), with Liu Yifei, Hiroshi Tamaki, Alec Su, Annie Yi, Qiu Xinzhi, Yao Lu, and Ni Dahong; The Last Tycoon (2012), with Sammo Hung, Francis Ng, and Huang Xiaoming; From Vegas to Macau (2014), with Nicholas Tse, Chapman To, and Jing Tian; and Soi Cheang’s The Monkey King (2014), with Donnie Yen, Donald Chow, Aaron Kwok, Joe Chen, and Peter Ho.

Films in the mid to late 2010s include From Vegas to Macau II (2015), with Nick Cheung, Carina Lau, Shawn Yue, Angela Wang, and Michelle Hu; Office (2015), with Sylvia Chang, Eason Chan, and Tang Wei; From Vegas to Macau III (2016), with Andy Lau, Nick Cheung, and Li Yuchun; Cold War 2 (2016), with Aaron Kwok, Tony Leung, Charlie Young, Eddie Peng, Aarif Rahman, Ma Yili, Janice Man, Tony Yang, and Bibi Zhou; and Felix Chong’s Project Gutenberg (2018), with Aaron Kwok, Zhang Jingchu, Joyce Feng, Liu Kai-chi, and Catherine Chau.

Each review will be linked to the title below.

(*seen originally in theaters)

(**seen rereleased in theaters)
